title: How to Season Pork Chops

steps.headline: Remove your pork chops from the refrigerator 30 minutes prior to cooking.
steps.description: You will ensure even cooking and a nice crust.

steps.headline: Sprinkle freshly ground black pepper and salt on one side of the chops.
steps.description: Sprinkle enough so that it is well covered. Pork chops benefit from quite a bit of seasoning.

steps.headline: Heat a pan on high heat.
steps.description: Then, add your oil and turn it down to medium heat.

steps.headline: Place your pork chops in the pan with a pair of tongs.
steps.description: Let them sear on one side until there’s a golden crust. Then, turn them.

steps.headline: Use a meat thermometer for the perfect doneness.
steps.description: When inserted into the center, it should read 135 °F (57.2 °C) (57 Celsius).

steps.headline: Allow the chops to rest on a cutting board, covered in foil, for 10 minutes.
steps.description: They will continue to cook and reach the 145-degree (63 Celsius) recommended temperature while remaining moist.

steps.headline: Remove the chops from the refrigerator 30 minutes before cooking.
Sprinkle both sides of the chops with garlic salt.
Mix the remainder of the spices and sugar in a bowl.
steps.description: Remember that you can adjust your spices to include almost any spice you like. Look for Tuscan, barbecue, Spanish and Indian spice rubs, as they pair well with pork.

steps.headline: Rub the spice mixture liberally on one side of the pork.
steps.description: Turn it over and rub the opposite side.

steps.headline: Heat up your skillet to high heat.
steps.description: Add your olive oil, and then turn it down to medium heat. Swirl the oil.

steps.headline: Place your chops in the skillet.
steps.description: Cook on one side for two minutes, or until golden brown.

steps.headline: Turn the pork chops over with tongs and cook for about four more minutes.
steps.description: Use a meat thermometer to ensure the internal temperature reaches 135 °F (57.2 °C) (57 Celsius). Once it does, rest it for 10 minutes on the cutting board. The pork will continue to cook and reach the preferred internal temperature of 145 degrees (63 Celsius).

text: Lightly Seasoning Pork Chops Remove your pork chops from the refrigerator 30 minutes prior to cooking. You will ensure even cooking and a nice crust. Pat the pork chops dry.  Sprinkle freshly ground black pepper and salt on one side of the chops. Sprinkle enough so that it is well covered. Pork chops benefit from quite a bit of seasoning. Turn the pork chops over. Repeat on the second side. Heat a pan on high heat. Then, add your oil and turn it down to medium heat. Place your pork chops in the pan with a pair of tongs. Let them sear on one side until there’s a golden crust. Then, turn them. Use a meat thermometer for the perfect doneness. When inserted into the center, it should read 135 °F (57.2 °C) (57 Celsius). Allow the chops to rest on a cutting board, covered in foil, for 10 minutes. They will continue to cook and reach the 145-degree (63 Celsius) recommended temperature while remaining moist. Spice Rubbing Pork Chops Remove the chops from the refrigerator 30 minutes before cooking.  Sprinkle both sides of the chops with garlic salt.  Mix the remainder of the spices and sugar in a bowl. Remember that you can adjust your spices to include almost any spice you like. Look for Tuscan, barbecue, Spanish and Indian spice rubs, as they pair well with pork. Rub the spice mixture liberally on one side of the pork. Turn it over and rub the opposite side. Heat up your skillet to high heat. Add your olive oil, and then turn it down to medium heat. Swirl the oil. Place your chops in the skillet. Cook on one side for two minutes, or until golden brown. Turn the pork chops over with tongs and cook for about four more minutes. Use a meat thermometer to ensure the internal temperature reaches 135 °F (57.2 °C) (57 Celsius). Once it does, rest it for 10 minutes on the cutting board. The pork will continue to cook and reach the preferred internal temperature of 145 degrees (63 Celsius). Finished.

Place your pork chops in the pan with a pair of tongs.
Let them sear on one side until there’s a golden crust.
Then, turn them.
Use a meat thermometer for the perfect doneness.
When inserted into the center, it should read 135 °F (57.2 °C) (57 Celsius).
Allow the chops to rest on a cutting board, covered in foil, for 10 minutes.

Spice Rubbing Pork Chops Remove the chops from the refrigerator 30 minutes before cooking.
Sprinkle both sides of the chops with garlic salt.
Mix the remainder of the spices and sugar in a bowl.
Remember that you can adjust your spices to include almost any spice you like.
Look for Tuscan, barbecue, Spanish and Indian spice rubs, as they pair well with pork.
Rub the spice mixture liberally on one side of the pork.
Turn it over and rub the opposite side.
Heat up your skillet to high heat.
Add your olive oil, and then turn it down to medium heat.
Swirl the oil.
Place your chops in the skillet.
Cook on one side for two minutes, or until golden brown.
Turn the pork chops over with tongs and cook for about four more minutes.
Use a meat thermometer to ensure the internal temperature reaches 135 °F (57.2 °C) (57 Celsius).
Once it does, rest it for 10 minutes on the cutting board.
The pork will continue to cook and reach the preferred internal temperature of 145 degrees (63 Celsius).
Finished.
